title: FF Call
content:
**[Indices](http://web.archive.org/web/20131023121343/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Indices) : [Typefaces](http://web.archive.org/web/20131023121343/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Typefaces) : FF Call**

Released by [FontFont](http://web.archive.org/web/20131023121343/http:/typophile.com/wiki/FontFont), 2000

For their work in cell phone advertising, the three designers ( [Maik Ignaszak](http://web.archive.org/web/20131023121343/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Maik%20Ignaszak), [Stefan Kisters](http://web.archive.org/web/20131023121343/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Stefan%20Kisters), and [Astrid Scheuerhorst](http://web.archive.org/web/20131023121343/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Astrid%20Scheuerhorst%20)) were constantly in need of display type for phones from Nokia, Motorola, Siemens, etc. As PostScript versions of these fonts weren't commercially available, either from the companies themselves or from various type libraries, they decided to make their own. The result is FF Call, a package of over 70 fonts from a dozen brands of cellular phones. Each design comes in three versions: Regular, Italic and Negative, plus Expert Sets.

Compatibility list:

FF Call One - Alcatel  
FF Call Two - Bosch  
FF Call Three - Ericsson  
FF Call Four - Motorola  
FF Call Five - Nokia  
FF Call Six - Panasonic  
FF Call Seven - Philips  
FF Call Eight - Siemens  
FF Call Nine - Sony

**External Links**  
 [FF Call at FontShop](http://web.archive.org/web/20131023121343/http:/www.fontshop.com/showfont.cfm?fid=FF.11200.0.0)
author: Stephen Coles
